Minor flooding could affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads and a small number of gardens in Crowhurst. From 12:00 on 05/01/2025, a small amount of water may also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. River levels in Crowhurst should initially begin to fall by 15:00 on 05/01/2025. However, further periods of rain are possible on Sunday and Monday, which could cause river levels to rise again, or slow the fall. River levels in Bulverhythe will remain higher than normal until midweek. River levels will hopefully not rise significantly higher than they were at New Years, and property flooding is not currently expected. However, as a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River is high and rising. Throughout the course of the night, heavy rain (23mm) has been recorded in Romsey. This is a large amount of rain in a short period of time. From 10:00 this morning 05/01/2025, the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the Mill building at East Wellow. Further rain is forecast over the next 6 hours. We expect the river will rise at least until 19:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025. Given the amount of rain currently affecting the area, by 18:00 it is it is possible that a Flood Warning will be issued for onset of isolated property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on Monday 06/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

25mm of rain has already been recorded at Cowbeech. Another 10mm of rain is possible before midday on Sunday (05/01/2025). More rain fell than was expected. Flooding will continue to affect fields and rural roads. From 08:30 on 05/01/2025, flooding will approach properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From 11:00 on 05/01/2025, flooding will also approach properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 13:00 on 05/01/2025, flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane and the Old Clergy House in Alfriston. Only showers are forecast on Sunday afternoon and Monday. Rivers should begin to fall by 21:00 on 05/01/2025 in Hellingly, and 09:00 on 06/01/2025 in Alfriston. Flood impacts could remain until Tuesday 07/01/2025. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 05/01/2025.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to Wymans Brook, Carrant Brook, Hatherley Brook, Swilgate and the River Chelt. Locations that may be affected include Mitton, Aschurch, Walton Cardiff and locations along the River Chelt from Charlton Kings to Uckington and Boddington.

The River Uck is high and rising. 25mm of rain has been recorded at Buxted early on Sunday morning. This is a lot of rain in a short period of time. Another 10mm of rain is possible before midday Sunday. Minor flooding will already be affecting fields. From 08:00 05/01/2025 flooding could affect gardens and approach riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub. In Uckfield, areas affected could include Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage & Bell Walk. Flood water will also affect fields and gardens at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. Only showers are forecast Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 05/01/2025, and return nearer to normal on Monday. River levels could end up similar to October and November 2024. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 05/01/2025

The Western Rother is high and rising. 32mm of rain has been recorded at Liss. From 14:00 05/01/2025, flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties including on Station Road next to the railway, Liss, and Mill Lane and Old Mill Lane, Sheet. From 18:00 05/01/2025, flooding will also affect gardens, and potentially Iping Lane and Stedham Lane, and approach properties in Iping, near Iping Bridge and Iping Mill. In Midhurst, flooding could affect North Mill and fields near the Cowdray ruins. From 22:00 05/01/2025, flood water will affect fields, gardens, rural roads and approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham, Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. Only a small amount of rain is forecast for Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall by Monday afternoon, but will be higher than normal until Tuesday evening. River levels could end up similar to late November 2024. Early actions to reduce potential impacts are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 05/01/2025.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the East Devon area. This has meant that the Rivers Clyst, Culm, and their tributaries are now rising. 
We expect rivers to remain high throughout today though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Sunday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Gloucester River gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected.   

  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill.    

  

Predicted peaks:- Mythe is currently peaking at between 2.75 to 3m. Gloucester is currently peaking at between 2.5 to 3m.  We are not expecting any impacts at other gauge locations 

  

Further rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Hellingly and Horsebridge on the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high and rising. 25mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech Saturday evening and Sunday morning. Another 5mm of rain is predicted before midday on Sunday. From 10:00 05/01/2025, flooding will affect fields, rural roads including Hammer Lane near Cowbeech, and properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly and at Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. From 14:00 05/01/2025, flooding will also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, including gardens and properties on those roads. Only showers are forecast Sunday afternoon and Monday. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly should begin to fall by 17:00 05/01/2025. The Bull River through Hellingly should begin to fall by 23:00 05/01/2025, returning nearer to normal on Monday afternoon 06/01/2025. River levels could peak higher than seen at the end of November 2024. Some roads may become impassable, including Mill Road and Church Road. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 on 05/01/2025.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

The River Ouse is high and rising. 20mm of rain has been recorded at Ardingly Saturday night. Another 5mm of rain is expected before midday Sunday. Only minimal flood impacts are expected near Ardingly. From 11:00 05/01/2025 minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and  gardens of properties on Sloop Lane. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will be affected. Flooding will likely affect the Anchor Inn and Anchor Lane, and might affect gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills road could become impassable. Only showers are predicted Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall by 22:00 05/01/2025 near Ardingly, but not until Monday morning in Barcombe. Flood impacts could remain until Monday evening. River levels will end up higher than at the New Year. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Barcombe Mills road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 05/01/2025

Further rainfall is forecast throughout today and into tomorrow morning, 6 January 2025. We expect river levels to remain high until this evening, 5 January 2025. Sunday afternoon's tide at 14:45 on 05/01/2025 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Westerly Force 6 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.32 m. The total forecast tide is 5.77 metres Chart Datum (2.72 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach, and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Monday's early morning tide at 03:00 on 06/01/2025 is forecast to be 29 cm higher (3.01 mAOD). Minor flood impacts are again expected over Monday's early morning tide, with the potential to experience a little more flood water than recent days. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 19:00 on 05/01/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Sunday morning the 5th of January.  High water at Plymouth is at 09:12am, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Spring tides are forecast to cause flooding between 8:12am and 10:12am.

Wave heights of up to 4m and Force 6 south-westerly winds will cause localised overtopping along exposed sections of the coastline.

Locations particularly at risk include low lying coastal communities.

Coastal conditions should ease for Sunday evening’s high tide; however, further flood alerts will be issued if necessary.

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 11am on Sunday, or sooner if the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.71 mAOD.  Expect tide levels along to coast to be between 0.4 and 0.5 metres above tide table level.  Moderate force 6 south-westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 4m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Dee.  River levels on the Dee have been steadily dropping but we expect them to rise again in response to recent snow and rainfall.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. We are not expecting to issue Flood Warnings.  

It is possible that Townfield Lane will be cut off.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Bewdley river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.   

  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke and Upton upon Severn. Install property level protection if required.    

  

Predicted peaks: Kempsey Yacht Club is currently peaking at between 4.6 to 5.1m. Saxons Lode is peaking at between 3.5 to 4m. We are not expecting any impacts at other gauge locations 

  

Further rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours and we may see river levels rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.    

 

This message will be updated by 11am on Monday, 06/01/25, or as the situation changes.

Flows in the Lower River Itchen at Mansbridge are high and increasing. In the last 14 hours, 22mm of rain has been recorded at Portswood. High tide at Southampton is expected at 14:30 and 16:15 on 05/01/2025 and is forecast at 4.85 metres Chart Datum (2.11 mAOD). For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the incoming tide will prevent the river from flowing to sea. This may cause the river to flood the access road and affect the car park near to the White Swan Pub at Mansbridge. Footpath flooding may also affect Riverside Park. Further rainfall (up to 15mm) is expected throughout Sunday 05/01/2025. Flow in the river will remain high and may increase after high tide and could cause flooding impacts over the next high tide forecast at 03:00 on Monday 06/01/2025. We continue to monitor the forecast and will remove reported blockages from the river. We recommend closing the defence gates around the pub at least an hour before high tide. This Flood Alert will be updated by 21:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025.

River levels are rising at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club is currently peaking at between 4.6 to 5.1m. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11am on Monday, 06/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Torridge (Lower) from Dolton to Bideford, including Taddiport and Weare Giffard
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Sunday morning.
Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Torridge area. This has meant that the River Torridge is now rising. 
Properties and low lying areas in Taddiport (properties around Taddiport Bridge, Sewage Treatment Works and B3227) and Weare Giffard (riverside properties and roads), will start to flood first from around 06:00 on Sunday. River levels will be at their highest between 06:45 and 09:00.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

The water level in the River Dun at Dunbridge is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 34mm of rain has been recorded at Romsey. This is a large volume in a short period of time. From 16:00 this afternoon (Sunday 05/01/2025), the river could come out of bank, causing road flooding at Rectory Road, nearest the railway line at West Dean. Most of the rain has now cleared the area but water levels will remain high until later this afternoon. Further rainfall (up to 10mm) is forecast tonight (05/01/2025) into tomorrow morning (06/01/2025). Out of bank flooding will continue until then, but property flooding is not currently expected. Our operations staff are ensuring the River Dun is free of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. At West Dean, we recommend moving any cars which are parked close to the river. Please also consider taking appropriate action now to protect your property. This Flood Alert will be updated by 09:00 on 06/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

At Brockenhurst water levels are high and rising. At Lymington, levels will be high over the next 12 hours. In the last 12 hours, 35mm of rain has been recorded in Brockenhurst. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. In Brockenhurst, there is flooding to roads, watersplash areas and gardens. At Lymington, high tide is forecast at 14:10 and 16:10 on Sunday 05/01/2025. Over high water, river levels will increase as they are unable to flow to sea. Lighter rain is forecast over the next 4 hours, which means that the river will remain high until at least this evening, before water levels fall. Property flooding is not currently expected. Further rain (up to 10mm) is forecast for tonight (05/01/2025). We will continue to monitor the forecast. Given an unsettled outlook, properties located nearest to the river should take appropriate action to ensure they can protect their property. This Flood Alert will be updated at 09:00 on 06/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding this afternoon. Flooding is expected when river levels are at their highest from 12:30 PM on 05/01/2025. River levels are forecast to peak early afternoon before starting to recede. Areas most at risk include Dorchester Road and Frome Lane area of Maiden Newton. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon. We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 06/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The River Lox is high and rising. 35mm of rain has been recorded at Chiddingfold on Saturday night into Sunday morning, which is a lot in a short period of time. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens are likely to already be occurring. From 15:00 on 05/01/2025, minor flooding could affect properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Flood water may also affect riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Only isolated showers are forecast for Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall by 23:00 on 05/01/2025, but will not return nearer to a normal level until Tuesday (07/01/2025). River levels could end up similar to those seen at the end of November 2024. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 06/01/2025.

The River Adur is high following Sunday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect isolated properties and farm buildings near Slaughter Bridge on the Coolham road, as well as fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield. Including fields near Church Close, Shipley. Only showers are forecast Sunday afternoon and Monday. River levels should begin to fall by 18:00 05/01/2025, but will not return nearer to a normal level until Monday afternoon. Some roads, including the Coolham road at Slaughter Bridge, may be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 06/01/2025.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St John's Station is high and rising. Heavy and intense rain has fallen with 24 mm in 10 hours recorded at Ryde. This is a large amount in a short period of time. From 07:30 this morning (Sunday 05/01/2025), water will begin to flow across the railway tracks, upstream of St John's Station. Rain will continue to affect the area over the next 6 hours with up to 10mm of rain expected. Water levels are unlikely to fall until 10:00, with flood impacts continuing until then. We will keep the river free of reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please consider moving vehicles from depots located next to the river and railway line. This Flood Alert will be updated by 21:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025.

The water level in the River Medina at Blackwater and Shide is high and rising. In the last 11 hours, 23mm of rain has been recorded in Cowes. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. From 06:30 this morning 05/01/2025, out of bank flooding will affect land, gardens and possibly roads at Blackwater, especially at Blackwater Hollow on the A3020 near Mill Farm and at Sandy Lane. At 07:00, the river will become very high at St George's Way, Shide. Rain will continue to affect the area over the next 6 hours with up to 10mm expected. Water levels are unlikely to fall until 13:00 05/01/2025 with flood impacts continuing until then. In the next 2 hours we may issue a flood warning for onset of property flooding from the river. We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. If you have it, we would encourage residents to install flood protection now. This Flood Alert will be updated at 21:00 on Sunday 05/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 32mm of rain has fallen at Wroxall. This is a significant amount in a short time. In the next 8 hours, water will be ponded on low lying land adjacent to the river throughout the river valley. Road, cycle track and footpath flooding is expected. At Langbridge and Alverstone Road Bridge, the river will be close to the top of the river bank. Property flooding is possible and further advice may be issued this afternoon. Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road, Sandown, may occur from early Monday morning 06/01/2025. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Light rain is forecast over the next 7 hours. At Alverstone, the river will rise until approximately 17:00 on Sunday afternoon (05/01/2025). At Sandown, levels will not peak until Monday morning (06/01/2025). We have checked the Bembridge sluice is operating normally. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens from flooding are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated at 11:00 on 06/01/2025.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Darent as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land near the river is possible from 11:00 AM today, 5 January 2025. Property flooding is not currently expected.

Further rainfall is forecast throughout today and into tomorrow morning, 6 January 2025. We expect river levels to remain high until this evening, 5 January 2025.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the river.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 8pm tonight, 5 January 2025, or as the situation changes.

The River Hamble at Durley and Botley is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 34mm of rain has been recorded in Bishops Waltham. In the next 30 minutes, Durley School may experience flood impacts as the Ford Lake will rise faster than the River Hamble. No property flooding is expected from the river at Bishops Waltham. At Botley, surface water flooding from the main road is possible. To aid sluice operation, high tide at Southampton is at 14:35 on 05/01/2025 with a forecast level of 2.11 mAOD (4.85 mCD). This is higher than normal. Further rain is forecast (up to 5mm) over the next 4 hours, and unsettled weather this evening. Water levels in the river are likely to remain very high for the next 6 hours. Given the forecast rainfall, over the next few hours, it is possible that a Flood Warning, for onset of property flooding from the river, will be issued for Durley and Botley. We will continue to monitor the forecast. We recommend installing flood protection at Durley School. This Flood Alert will be updated at 09:00 on 06/01/2025 or sooner if we think property flooding will occur.

The River Arun is high and rising. 30mm of rain has been recorded at Itchingfield on Saturday night and Sunday morning. From 12:00 on 05/01/2025, minor flooding could affect grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court, and possibly fields behind Arunside and the playground of Arunside School. From 15:00 on 05/01/2025, flood water will affect fields and gardens of isolated mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay. From 22:00 on 05/01/2025, flood water could approach properties at Pallingham Lock. Only showers are forecast for Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall in Horsham by 22:00 on 05/01/2025, but not until 16:00 on 06/01/2025 near Pallingham. River levels near Pulborough could remain higher than normal until midweek. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 22:00 on 05/01/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:

Flooding is possible throughout Sunday into Monday as river levels rise due to heavy rainfall.  Rain is expected to continue throughout Sunday and into Monday morning.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Further light rainfall is possible overnight and into Monday 06/01/2025.
This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 05/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Barcombe Mills on the River Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising. 30mm of rain has been recorded on the top of the Ouse and the Uck on Saturday night into Sunday morning. This is a lot of rain in a short period of time. From 15:30 on 05/01/2025, flooding will be extensive through fields. Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane are likely to be impassable. The Anchor Inn is expected to flood. From 18:00 on 05/01/2025, flood water might affect gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Only isolated showers are forecast for Sunday afternoon and Monday. The river should begin to fall by 08:00 on 06/01/2025, and return nearer to a normal level by Tuesday afternoon (07/01/2025). River levels could end up similar to those in May 2024. Some roads may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 on 06/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have slowly started to recede. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. There is rain forecast for 1st Jan 2025.

After New Year's Day the forecast is for high pressure to build over the next 3-5 days which should see groundwater levels continue to fall.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 7/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are slowly rising at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, the rate of rise has slowed as a result of recent more settled weather. 

Groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week. We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 07/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley as a result of recent settled weather. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again following prolonged rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 07/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and remain relatively stable after a week of dry weather. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, the level is very close to causing cellar flooding impacts to a small number of properties. It is also very close to reducing the ability of septic tanks in Old Alresford to operate effectively. Tomorrow (01/01/2025), unsettled weather is forecast to move over Hampshire bringing between 10 and 20mm of rain. From Thursday (02/01/2025) to Saturday (04/01/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. If the heaviest rain in the forecast affects the area, then it is possible that groundwater levels will rise high enough for cellar flooding and septic tank impacts to occur. We continue to monitor the forecast. We advise residents to remain prepared for flooding impacts this winter. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 07/01/2025.

Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday the 8th of January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday the 8th of January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton as a result of recent rainfall. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue slowly rising over the next few weeks and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 07/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Lukely Brook at Newport is high and rising. In the last 11 hours, 24mm of rain has fallen at Carisbrooke. This is a large volume in a short period of time. Currently, the river is near to bank full. From 06:30 this morning (05/01/2025) flooding may affect land at Vicarage Walk. We are not expecting impacts from the river at Carisbrooke. The river may also come out of bank from Old Westminster Lane to Hunnycross Way, flooding footpaths. Further heavy rain is forecast over the next 6 hours. If levels continue to rise, in the next 1 to 2 hours we may issue a Flood Warning, for onset of property flooding directly from the river. Vulnerable areas are Old Westminster Lane, and the Aquatics Centre at Vicarage Walk near Foxes Road. Our operational contractors will ensure the river is kept free of any reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. At Vicarage Walk, we encourage residents living nearest the river to take action to protect their property. This Flood Alert will be updated at 21:00 on 05/01/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk include the Corfe Castle and Swanage areas. Further flooding is possible throughout the morning as river levels are expected to remain high due to further rainfall. We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Danes Stream is very high. In the last 13 hours, 27mm of rain has been recorded at Stem Lane. This is a significant amount in a short time. Milford Dam has operated correctly to reduce the amount of water flowing to Milford on Sea. However, the water level in the village is very high and some footpath flooding is occurring. Gardens at Milford on Sea High Street may also be affected. No impacts are expected at Ashley. Following high tide this afternoon (Sunday 05/01/2025), the level in the river should begin to reduce. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please keep away from the riverside footpaths in Milford on Sea, especially at Milford Bridge opposite Lucerne Road during Sunday 05/01/2025. If footpaths are flooded it will be difficult to see where the edge of the main river channel is. This Flood Alert will be updated at 12:00 on Monday 06/01/2025.

The water level in the Lavant Stream is rising rapidly. At Crossland Drive, the debris screen is currently blocked. This is as a result of heavy and intense rain, with 15mm in 12 hours recorded at Havant, which has washed large pieces of debris down the river. Our operational staff are travelling to the site to remove the blockage. From 10:00 this morning (Sunday 05/01/2025) it is possible that the river may come out of bank, affecting gardens of property located immediately either side of the river at Crossland Drive. We are not expecting impacts at Eastern Road or in Havant Town Centre. Although further rain is expected over the next 6 hours, once the blockage is removed, water levels will remain high but shouldn’t continue to be a risk to property. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure debris screens in Havant remain free of blockages. Please take appropriate action to protect your property, installing flood protection if you have it. This Flood Alert will be updated by 09:00 on 06/01/2025.

items.description: Blackwater and Newport on the River Medina
items.message: The water level in the River Medina at Blackwater and Newport is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, heavy and intense rain has fallen, with 34mm recorded at Carisbrooke. From 10:30 this morning (Sunday 05/01/2025) in Blackwater, near Mill Farm, the river could flood Blackwater Mill buildings and property at Sandy Lane. Property on the riverbank at St George's Way may also flood. Further rain is forecast over the next 6 hours, with up to 10mm possible. This will cause the river to remain high until later this evening (Sunday 05/01/2025). Our operational staff are out on site checking that the river is free of blockages. We will continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection or take appropriate action to protect property. This Flood Warning will be updated by 21:00 on 05/01/2025.

items.description: River Avon from Didworthy to Aveton Gifford
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Sunday morning and into the afternoon.
Over the last 18 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the South Devon area. This is causing the River Avon to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising through the day.
Properties and low lying areas in South Brent, Avonwick, Brushford and Manor House near Diptford
Gara Bridge, Loddiswell  and Aveton Gifford will start to flood first from around 10:30am on Sunday. 
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads at 7:00 PM on 05/01/2025 
Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of the high tide.
Areas most at risk include beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
After the high tide this evening‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/01/2025, or as the situation changes.
